artist: Artist: Marcantonio Raimondi; Artist: After Raphael (Raffaello Sanzio)
catalogue_raissonne: Bartsch XIV.12.10 (first state, before tablet with MAF monogram); Delaborde XI.1
inscription:
Inscription and Marks

Inscribed, on verso, LC, in pen and brown ink: [De Valois], Lugt 2479; and LLC: ?[sfih.] (price code?)
markings:
Collector\'s marks, on verso, LLC
Stamped in black ink: [JM] Lugt 1494
Stamped in violet ink [IR] Lugt 1523
provenance: Charles de Valois, Lugt 2479, Paris (until d.1799; his sale, F.Regnault-Delalande, Paris, December 14-19, 1801 [23-28 frimaire an X], no. 231); Julian Marshall, Lugt 1494, London (until 1864; his sale, Sotheby's, London, June 30-July 10, 1864, no. 1573, for £36, to Grundy; James Reiss, Lugt 1523 (1812-1899), Manchester and London; Herschel V. Jones, Minneapolis (until 1926; gave to MIA)
text:
Around 1517–19, artists from Raphael’s workshop frescoed the interior of a loggia, a long open-sided passageway, in the Vatican. On the ceiling of the eleventh bay is this scene of David beheading Goliath. 

According to the Books of Samuel from the Bible, the young David, future king of Israel, felled the Philistine warrior Goliath using a simple sling and stone. Here David is set to behead Goliath with the fallen giant’s own sword. Viewers in the 1500s would immediately have interpreted David as Christ, Goliath as Satan, and the Israelites as the Church Triumphant.

The engraving differs from the finished fresco in many details. Marcantonio likely based his work on a now-lost drawing by Raphael or a preparatory work by one of his assistants.
title: David Beheading Goliath
